title: Wikiwand - Traditional African medicine
description: Traditional African medicine is a range of traditional medicine disciplines involving indigenous herbalism and African spirituality, typically including diviners, midwives, and herbalists. Practitioners of traditional African medicine claim, largely without evidence, to be able to cure a variety of diverse conditions including cancer, psychiatric disorders, high blood pressure, cholera, most venereal diseases, epilepsy, asthma, eczema, fever, anxiety, depression, benign prostatic hyperplasia, urinary tract infections, gout, and healing of wounds and burns and even Ebola.
cleaned_text: Traditional African medicine Traditional medical practices in Africa / From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Dear Wikiwand AI, let's keep it short by simply answering these key questions: Can you list the top facts and stats about Traditional African medicine? Summarize this article for a 10 years old Traditional African medicine is a range of [traditional medicine](/en/Traditional_medicine) disciplines involving [indigenous](/en/Indigenous_peoples_of_Africa) [herbalism](/en/Herbalism) and [African spirituality](/en/Traditional_African_religions), typically including [diviners](/en/Divination), midwives, and [herbalists](/en/Herbalism). Practitioners of traditional African medicine claim, largely without evidence, to be able to cure a variety of diverse conditions including cancer, psychiatric disorders, high blood pressure, [cholera](/en/Cholera), most venereal diseases, [epilepsy](/en/Epilepsy), [asthma](/en/Asthma), [eczema](/en/Eczema), fever, anxiety, depression, [benign prostatic hyperplasia](/en/Benign_prostatic_hyperplasia), urinary tract infections, gout, and healing of wounds and burns and even [Ebola](/en/Ebola). [[1]](#cite_note-Helwig2005-1) [[2]](#cite_note-Times1-2) Diagnosis is reached through spiritual means and a treatment is prescribed, usually consisting of a herbal remedy that is considered to have not only healing abilities but also symbolic and spiritual significance. Traditional African medicine, with its belief that illness is not derived from chance occurrences, but through spiritual or social imbalance, differs greatly from modern [scientific medicine](/en/Medicine), which is technically and analytically based. In the 21st century, modern pharmaceuticals and medical procedures remain inaccessible to large numbers of African people due to their relatively high cost and concentration of health facilities in urban centres. [[3]](#cite_note-Ubani-3) [Traditional medicine](/en/Traditional_medicine) was the dominant medical system for millions of people in Africa prior the arrival of the [Europeans](/en/Ethnic_groups_in_Europe), who introduced evidence-based medicine, which was a noticeable turning point in the history of this tradition and culture. [[4]](#cite_note-Abdullahi2011-4) Herbal medicines in Africa are generally not adequately researched, and are weakly regulated. [[5]](#cite_note-Mills2005-5) There is a lack of the detailed documentation of the [traditional knowledge](/en/Traditional_knowledge), which is generally transferred orally. [[6]](#cite_note-van_Wyk-6) Serious [adverse effects](/en/Adverse_effect) can result from misidentification or misuse of healing plants. [[1]](#cite_note-Helwig2005-1) The [geographical reach](/en/Geography) of this article is [Sub-Saharan Africa](/en/Sub-Saharan_Africa). Though, of course [neighbouring](/en/Neighbourhood) medical traditions influenced traditional African medicine.
